newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Serb presidency member signs oath to Bosnian state.
newsitem.headline: Serb presidency member signs oath to Bosnian state.

text.p: The Serb member of Bosnia's collective presidency signed an oath of loyalty to Bosnian statehood on Tuesday in Sarajevo, effectively renouncing Serb war aims to carve out a separate state.

Momcilo Krajisnik, a hardline Serb nationalist, signed the declaration pledging to uphold Bosnia's constitution and the Dayton peace agreement shortly after 8 p.m. (1800 GMT) as foreign dignitaries and reporters looked on.
Krajisnik had refused to sign the oath three weeks ago, boycotting an inauguration ceremony in Sarajevo national theatre.
But the man who peace mediators once dubbed "Mr No" bowed to international pressure on Tuesday.
He had to sign the declaration in Sarajevo's battered national museum, which was repeatedly fired on by Serb gunners laying siege to the city during the war.
Wearing an elegant blue suit, Krajisnik smiled after signing the oath in a small room in the national museum, which straddles a former front line that cut through the city.
Krajisnik then shook hands with the Moslem chair of the presidency, Alija Izetbegovic, and the Croat member, Kresimir Zubak.
"It was a big effort for me to come to Sarajevo after what happened to the Serbs from Sarajevo but I do not regret coming," he said.
"...If this small sacrifice is a contribution to the peace then I will be happy."
Diplomats, including U.S. President Bill Clinton's envoy, John Kornblum, applauded the signing and called it a step forward for the peace process.
Krajisnik helped lead a Serb nationalist rebellion against the Bosnian government when it broke from Serbian-dominated Yugoslavia in 1992.

But Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, widely blamed for igniting the conflict, later forced his Serb proteges to accept a peace treaty that preserves Bosnia as a loose union comprised of a Serb republic and a Moslem-Croat federation.
The signing took place at a session of the three-man presidency which met in Sarajevo on Tuesday for the second time since post-war general elections were held on September 14.
Krajisnik ruined a ceremony three weeks ago at the national theatre, pulling out at the last moment after forcing Western diplomast to wait for hours as his chair stood empty on the stage.
Izetbegovic and Zubak signed the same "solemn declaration" at the earlier ceremony.
After about four hours of talks, the presidency members said they would meet again on Friday on the outskirts of Sarajevo in Serb-held territory and again next week in the city centre.
All three men signed an agreement pledging support to common institutions which are supposed to govern Bosnia under terms of the U.S.-brokered Dayton peace accord reached last November.
The agreement calls for the presidency to meet alternately in Moslem-Croat federation territory or Serb territory in a compromise devised to settle a two-month old dispute.
The collective presidency had been plagued by an argument over where the body should meet.
Krajisnik has resisted holding presidency sessions in Sarajevo, which separatist Serb forces besieged during the Bosnian conflict.

The three men agreed to a "provisional arrangement" in which the presidency would meet at the national museum in the city centre or at the electrical engineering faculty in the Serb-held suburb of Lukavica.
At least every third session would be held in Serb territory, according to the accord.
